Parameters.Conditions: FAO ecological zone: Temperate mountain system; vegetation type: Trees, conifer (needleleaf) evergreen; species/forest composition: Pinus cembra; stand age: 90; soil type: Haplic podzol
Region.Regional.conditions: country: Austria; nearest city: Innsbruck; geographic coordinates: 47.21028, 11.45194; elevation: 1950 m; continent: Europe; Koeppen climate zone: Dfc; mean annual temperature: 2.4 degrees C; annual precipitation: 950 mm yr-1
Other.Properties: ForC site: Klimahaus Research Station (ID#: 2765); ForC plot: Temperate Evergreen Forest. Stand established around 1912 (ID#: 3888); ForC measurement ID: 24692; Date of Measurement: 2002; variable description: Total live biomass (above and below-ground).
Full.Technical.Reference: Wieser, G.; Stohr, D. (2005) Net Ecosystem Carbon Dioxide Exchange Dynamics in a Pinus cembra Forest at the Upper Timberline in the Central Austrian Alps (233-242)
Abstract.in.English: WlESER G. & STÖHR D. 2005. Net ecosystem carbon dioxide exchange dynamics in a Pinus cembra forest at the alpine timberline in the Central Austrian Alps. - Phyton (Horn, Austria) 45 (3): (233)-(242). We studied net ecosystem carbon exchange dynamics in a cembran pine (Pinus cembra L.) forest ecosystem at the timberline ecotone of the Central European Alps from October 7, 2001 throughout January 21, 2003. Chamber measurements of CO2 gas exchange of the foliage, woody tissue respiration, and soil surface CO2 efflux were used to identify the contribution of these components to the net ecosystem CO2 exchange. We scaled these measurements to the ecosystem and computed the annual total of net ecosystem carbon sequestration and total ecosystem respiration. Seasonal variations in net ecosystem carbon exchange dynamics were primarily controlled by the prevailing temperature and irradiance. Annual net primary production estimated for 2002 was 1610 g C m"2 y"'and total ecosystem respiration was 1247 g C m"2 year"1 . Annual carbon efflux from the foliage, branches, stems, coarse roots, and the soil surface was 273, 846, 45, 50, and 33 g C m"~ year" , respectively. Net ecosystem production was 363 g C m"2 year"1 , leading to a ratio of net ecosystem production to gross primary production of 0.23, consistent with values reported for temperate coniferous forest ecosystems, but higher than values reported for boreal coniferous forests. Due to low soil temperature and supra-optimal soil water availability soil surface carbon efflux was relatively low and contributed to only 3% to total ecosystem respiration. Nevertheless, our data indicate that timberline associated Pinus cembra forest ecosystems in the Central Austrian Alps act as relative powerful carbon sinks.
Comments.from.Data.Provider: confidence notes: 95%CI is NA because only 1 plot was measured; Data imported from the Global Forest Carbon database (ForC; https://forc-db.github.io/) : Anderson-Teixeira, K. J., M. M. H. Wang, J. C. McGarvey, V. Herrmann, A. J. Tepley, B. P. Bond-Lamberty, and D. S. LeBauer (2018) ForC: a global database of forest carbon stocks and fluxes. Ecology. DOI: 10.1002/ecy.2229.
Data.Provider: SRDB database (lead: Ben Bond Lamberty, Pacific Northwest National Lab), via ForC (lead: Kristina Anderson-Teixeira, Smithsonian Institution)
